J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> Pat Farrell wrote:
>  > It is not clear to me how to use JUnit to test multi-thread applications.
>  >
>  > Is it possible?
>  > Any hints and tips?
> 
> I haven't done much multithreading work
> myself, since I tend to use platforms that do that for me. That's why I
> don't have specific advice for you, except to make the threading
> pluggable so that you can test your logic in a single-threaded mode
> first. I'd hate to be looking for logic and threading problems together.

Yes, debugging multi-threaded stuff is hard. We used to let Operating 
Systems developers do it, and pay them big bucks.

But nearly all of my Java development is in a multi-threaded world.
I'm surprized that you don't run into it. Nearly every thing I do
is run as a servlet, so you have to be thread safe. And all of my 
systems have assorted daemons and background threads, which implement 
simple things like WorkingSetCaches or do long things like
talking to radios that have to be dispatched asynchronously.

And the AJAX folks are pushing the multi-threaded model even harder,
with many more server clanks, and more chances for the server to get 
wrapped arround the axel with thread issues.
